awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: From knowledge consumers to knowledge producers: A scalable experiential learning approach for psychology and related disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
STEM education provides both technical training and the development of cognitive skills, such as designing experiments, testing hypotheses, and analyzing data.  While traditional STEM training is essential for developing a highly skilled technical workforce, the cognitive skills developed through this training are beneficial in almost every type of career.  To provide cognitive skills training to undergraduates in psychology, who typically do not receive this type of education, this project will develop a computer program, named TELLab, that allows psychology students to design experiments and gather data using the internet.  Using this program, students will have the opportunity to experience first hand the challenges of doing science, learning skills and concepts, and most importantly, formulating and solving problems of personal interest to them.

To this end, the proposal has three broadly defined goals: (1) Up-scaling and maturation of TELLab, so that it can handle hundreds of thousands of users, in countless numbers of classrooms, with students at all levels - all at the same time, (2) evaluation of TELLlab-based pedagogy in diverse settings, including evaluating STEM competencies in non-STEM students, particularly those in undergraduate psychology classes, and (3) advancing the effort to create an open source community of faculty and students across the nation to develop and sustain collective expertise.  Through a collaborative partnership across a variety of institutions, TELLab modules will be developed and deployed in a variety of psychology courses.  These modules will allow students to design experiments and test hypotheses, providing immersion in the cognitive skills that are at the core of STEM education.  Course instructors and participating students will be evaluated to identify and assess the factors that influence student experiences and learning.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-IUSE award to UC San Diego was part of a larger funded collaboration between researchers at Harvard, Wellesley, Princeton, and UC Berkeley.  Our research investigated the novel use of an active online learning platform called The Experiential Learning Laboratory (TELLab), which was funded primarily through the grant to Harvard/UC Berkeley. UC San Diego’s role was to test the usefulness of this tool at a large public university and to provide both quantitative and qualitative feedback about how to improve TELLab.

TELLab is a web-based multi-level software system that allows students to conduct classic experiments on themselves and others, to adapt and change them, to ask new questions and to compare their own results to hundreds of other participants in their own classes as well as others at different universities. Using robust paradigms of experimental, cognitive and social psychology where students can be both subject and experimenter, we created an experiential learning framework designed to maximize student engagement along a series of steps starting with the replication of classic experiments, followed by allowing easy adaptations of these studies with a graphical user interface that allows editing them, and ultimately leading to students creating new experiments at more advanced levels. By the end of this grant, more than 1000 experiments had been publicly posted using this platform.

At UCSD we incorporated the use of TELLAB in a variety of ways into courses — both large courses, like Cognitive Psychology, as well as honors’ theses and summary research programs — in order to test how well students learned from TELLab and how this contrasted with other, existing systems that often come bundled with textbooks.  Thousands of students used TELLab and provided extensive feedback on it. Overall, they rated it very highly: approximately 90% of students at UCSD said they learned something important about how psychology is done from doing the TELLab assignments in our courses, and the qualitative feedback — particularly from those using it to edit and adapt an existing experiment for their own question — was very strong.
